investigators: Dee, S.G.; Cobb, K.M.; Emile-Geay, J.; Ault, T.R.; Edwards, R.L.; Cheng, H.; Charles, C.D.
studyNotes: Monthly-resolved coral aragonite oxygen isotope (d18O) data from Palmyra Island from modern and fossil corals, 1146-2006 CE

author.name: Sylvia G. Dee, Kim M. Cobb, Julien Emile-Geay, Toby R. Ault, R. Lawrence Edwards, Hai Cheng, Christopher D. Charles

publication.title: No consistent ENSO response to volcanic forcing over the last millennium
publication.citation: Sylvia G. Dee, Kim M. Cobb, Julien Emile-Geay, Toby R. Ault, R. Lawrence Edwards, Hai Cheng, Christopher D. Charles. 2020. No consistent ENSO response to volcanic forcing over the last millennium. Science, 367(6485), 1477-1481. doi: 10.1126/science.aax2000
publication.abstract: The El Nino-Southern Oscillation (ENSO) shapes global climate patterns yet its sensitivity to external climate forcing remains uncertain. Modeling studies suggest that ENSO is sensitive to sulfate aerosol forcing associated with explosive volcanism but observational support for this effect remains ambiguous. Here, we used absolutely dated fossil corals from the central tropical Pacific to gauge ENSO's response to large volcanic eruptions of the last millennium. Superposed epoch analysis reveals a weak tendency for an El Nino-like response in the year after an eruption, but this response is not statistically significant, nor does it appear after the outsized 1257 Samalas eruption. Our results suggest that those models showing a strong ENSO response to volcanic forcing may overestimate the size of the forced response relative to natural ENSO variability.

paleoData.dataTableNotes: This record includes both modern and fossil corals at monthly resolution. 10th-13th Century Piece: 1146-1464 CE.  16th Century Piece: 1635-1703 CE.  Modern Pieces: 1886-2006 CE
